content.2p: The %kScanner%/k class is used to read user input from the console:%c Scanner scanner = new Scanner(System.in);%nString input = scanner.nextLine();%/c
content.3p: Java provides the %kFileReader%/k and %kFileWriter%/k classes for basic file operations. To read a file:%c FileReader reader = new FileReader(%'file.txt%');%/c To write to a file:%c FileWriter writer = new FileWriter(%'file.txt%');%/c
content.4p: Java offers %bInputStream%/b and %bOutputStream%/b for handling byte streams. These classes are essential for reading and writing binary data.
content.5p: Serialization converts an object into a byte stream for storage or transmission using %kObjectOutputStream%/k. Deserialization reconstructs the object from the byte stream using %kObjectInputStream%/k.
content.6p: File and stream operations often throw %bIOExceptions%/b, which must be handled using %ktry-catch%/k blocks to prevent program crashes.

question1.question: Which class is used to read user input from the console?

feedback.1: Incorrect. BufferedReader reads from streams, but Scanner is more commonly used for console input.
feedback.2: Correct! Scanner is used for reading user input from the console.
feedback.3: Not quite. InputStream is a more general class for byte input.
feedback.4: Incorrect. FileReader is used for reading files, not console input.

question2.question: True/False: The FileReader class is used to write data to a file.

feedback.1: Incorrect. FileReader is used for reading files, not writing.
feedback.2: That's right! FileWriter is used for writing data to a file.
